procedures.procedure: Physical examination and clinical assessment based on presenting symptoms
Imaging study to confirm diagnosis
Use ultrasound to investigate tears
Check if plantarflexion of the ankle is weak.
Patient lies prone and the calf is squeezed. If tendon is ruptured, the foot will remain still when it ought to contract involuntarily.
Use ultrasound to confirm the diagnosis.
Radiographic imaging to assess bony structures and joint alignment.
Check for density of apophysitis and check for fragmentation of the apophysitis.
Physical examination and clinical assessment based on presenting symptoms

recommendedTests: Confirmation using ultrasound to check for thickening around the heel.
Doppler test to show increased local blood flow and neovascularisation

procedures.testName: Confirmation using ultrasound to check for thickening around the heel.
procedures.procedure: Ultrasound imaging to assess soft tissue structures.

procedures.testName: Doppler test to show increased local blood flow and neovascularisation
procedures.procedure: Perform clinical test as described in standard protocols.
Physical examination and clinical assessment based on presenting symptoms
Imaging study to confirm diagnosis

recommendedTests: Special Test for Recurrent Lateral Instability

procedures.procedure: The ankle is held in the neutral position, examiner stabilised the tibia just above the ankle and then tries to force the ankle into maximum inversion. The ROM can be measured or compared with the contralateral side.Inversion laxity suggests injury to calcaneofibular and anterior talofibular ligaments (ATFL).

Patient sits with knee flexed at 90 deg and ankle in plantarflexion of about 10 deg. The lower leg is stabilised by the examiner and the force patient’s heel forward over the tibia. If positive, the talus can be felt sliding forwards and backwards. Laxity indicates tear of the ATFL.

procedures.testName: Special Test for Recurrent Lateral Instability
procedures.procedure: Perform clinical test as described in standard protocols.
Imaging study to confirm diagnosis
Check if foot is everted and externally rotated.
Check for widening of the medial joint space in the mortise view, check if talus is tilted, check for fracture or dislocation of the proximal fibula.
Compress the leg firmly above the ankle. Test is positive if pain is felt over the syndesmosis.
Radiographic imaging to assess bony structures and joint alignment.
Radiographic imaging to assess bony structures and joint alignment.
Imaging study to confirm clinical diagnosis.
Check if two-point discrimination is present.
Check if pain is present on passive movement of the toes
Imaging study to confirm diagnosis
Check for the following deformities
Check for osteoporosis, and periarticular erosion at the metatarsophalangeal joint.

recommendedTests: Radiographic confirmation. Check for osteoporosis, erosion of the tarsal and ankle joints and the swelling of soft-tissues.

procedures.testName: Radiographic confirmation. Check for osteoporosis, erosion of the tarsal and ankle joints and the swelling of soft-tissues.
procedures.procedure: Radiographic imaging to assess bony structures and joint alignment.

recommendedTests: Radiographic confirmation – check for joint space narrowing, osteophytes formation, subchondral sclerosis, and cyst formation.

procedures.testName: Radiographic confirmation – check for joint space narrowing, osteophytes formation, subchondral sclerosis, and cyst formation.
procedures.procedure: Radiographic imaging to assess bony structures and joint alignment.
Check if there:
Percussion of the tarsal tunnel. Positive if this results in a distal radiation of paraesthesia
Place the patient’s foot into dorsiflexion and eversion and hold for 5-10 seconds. Positive if patient’s symptom is elicited.
Check for atrophy of the abductor hallucis
Check for arch stability
Check for the position of the talus and calcaneus

recommendedTests: Spurling’s Test (Maximal Cervical Compression and Foraminal Compression Test)

procedures.testName: Spurling’s Test (Maximal Cervical Compression and Foraminal Compression Test)
procedures.procedure: The neck is placed in extension, lateral flexion, and axial compression. The test is positive if pain is present and radiates to the arm.

The patient lies supine and the neck is positioned comfortably.  The examiner places hand around the patient’s mastoid process. The examiner then slightly flexes the patient’s neck and pull the head towards your torso.Test is positive if the symptoms reduces or is eliminated with traction.
Radiographic imaging to assess bony structures and joint alignment.
Check if cervical rotation on the affected side is less than 60 degrees.
MRI imaging study to visualize soft tissue structures and confirm diagnosis.

recommendedTests: Spurling’s Test (Maximal Cervical Compression and Foraminal Compression Test)

procedures.testName: Spurling’s Test (Maximal Cervical Compression and Foraminal Compression Test)
procedures.procedure: The neck is placed in extension, lateral flexion, and axial compression. The test is positive if pain is present and radiates to the arm.
check for loss of normal cervical lordosis, and degeneration.

recommendedTests: Patient resists wrist flexion with the forearm in extension and supination (i.e. therapist resists wrist extension with the forearm in extension and supination)
The test is positive if pain is elicited.

procedures.procedure: Perform clinical test as described in standard protocols.
Resisted extension of the middle finger elicits pain
Pain on resisted wrist extension
Pt closes hands, dorsiflexes wrist and elbow is extended. The examiner then forces the wrist into palmar flexion against resistance; pain in the epicondyle is positive.

procedures.testName: Patient resists wrist flexion with the forearm in extension and supination (i.e. therapist resists wrist extension with the forearm in extension and supination)
procedures.procedure: Perform clinical test as described in standard protocols.

procedures.testName: The test is positive if pain is elicited.

recommendedTests: Test is positive if the biceps tendon cannot be hooked

procedures.procedure: Perform clinical test as described in standard protocols.
Palpate for biceps tendon in the antecubital fossa with arms flexed, shoulder ABducted and forearm in supination.

procedures.testName: Test is positive if the biceps tendon cannot be hooked
procedures.procedure: Perform clinical test as described in standard protocols.
Check for osteopenia, bone erosions, destruction of the radial head and widening of the sigmoid notch.Other laboratories tests as may be necessary

recommendedTests: Radiographic confirmation – Check for joint space narrowing, osteophyte formation, and subchondral sclerosis.

procedures.testName: Radiographic confirmation – Check for joint space narrowing, osteophyte formation, and subchondral sclerosis.
procedures.procedure: Radiographic imaging to assess bony structures and joint alignment.

Examiner raises legs of patient up so that hip flexion is achieved while knee is extended. Test is positive if patient feels pain along the course of the sciatic nerve and below the knee when hip is between 30 - 70 degrees of flexion.
This is a modification of the SLR and dorsiflexion is applied at the end of the SLR. This reduces the angle where the test is positive.

recommendedTests: Bowstring Test (Popliteal Compression Test/ Tibial Nerve Stretch Sign)

procedures.procedure: Examiner raises legs of patient up so that hip flexion is achieved while knee is extended. Test is positive if patient feels pain along the course of the sciatic nerve and below the knee when hip is between 30 - 70 degrees of flexion.
This is a modification of the SLR and dorsiflexion is applied at the end of the SLR. This reduces the angle where the test is positive.

procedures.testName: Bowstring Test (Popliteal Compression Test/ Tibial Nerve Stretch Sign)
procedures.procedure: This can be done while patient is lying in supine or sitting position. The examiner flexes the knee and applies pressure on the popliteal fossa evoking sciatica.
Check if knee jerk reflex is present
Check if ankle jerk reflex is present

Record the amount of time the patient spends on a cycle ergometer while in a neutral lumbar position and slumped position. If patient spends more time in the slumped position, a lumbar spinal stenosis is indicated.
The patient walks on a flat treadmill and the amount of time spent is recorded and compared with the amount of time while the treadmill is inclined such that patient walks in flexion.
The examiner ensures that the lumbar region is in moderate extension (10-30 deg) while standing and patient lies supine. Check if there are changes in the symptoms that the patient feels.
Check if a wide-based gait is present
Check if Trendenlenburg’s sign is present
Check if Achilles tendon reflex is diminished

recommendedTests: Bowstring Test (Popliteal Compression Test/ Tibial Nerve Stretch Sign)

procedures.procedure: Examiner raises legs of patient up so that hip flexion is achieved while knee is extended. Test is positive if patient feels pain along the course of the sciatic nerve and below the knee when hip is between 30 - 70 degrees of flexion.
This is a modification of the SLR and dorsiflexion is applied at the end of the SLR. This reduces the angle where the test is positive.

procedures.testName: Bowstring Test (Popliteal Compression Test/ Tibial Nerve Stretch Sign)
procedures.procedure: This can be done while patient is lying in supine or sitting position. The examiner flexes the knee and applies pressure on the popliteal fossa evoking sciatica.
Patient is in prone position, knee is flexed and hip is extended. Reproduction of pain in anterior thigh is positive.
Patient’s neck is flexed, hip flexed and the leg is extended. Pain is reproduced in this position.
pain is reproduced on straight leg elevation for 30 seconds.
Radiographic imaging to assess bony structures and joint alignment.
Check for tenderness in the paraspinal musculature
Check for spasms in the paraspinal musculature
Check for decreased reflexes: patellar and ankle jerk
Check for trendenenburg’s sign
MRI imaging study to visualize soft tissue structures and confirm diagnosis.
Radiographic imaging to assess bony structures and joint alignment.
Check for babinski sign and clonus to rule out upper motor neuron involvement

recommendedTests: Lateral lumbar flexion (Finger tip to Floor Test)

The patient stands with heel touching wall and feet wide apart, and back against the wall. Then the examiner measures the distance from middle finger to the floor. Then patient bends to side (lateral flexion)
Chest expansion- Normal chest expansion is ≥ 5 cm.
Occiput to wall distance- Normally is 0
Tragus to wall distance- Normally is < 15cm

procedures.testName: Lateral lumbar flexion (Finger tip to Floor Test)
procedures.procedure: Perform clinical test as described in standard protocols.

procedures.testName: The patient stands with heel touching wall and feet wide apart, and back against the wall. Then the examiner measures the distance from middle finger to the floor. Then patient bends to side (lateral flexion)
procedures.procedure: . The distance between the middle finger and the floor is measured again. This measurement is done for both sides.

Examiner marks both posterior superior iliac spine, and a horizontal line is drawn between both marks. A second line is marked 5cm below the first line, and a third line is marked 10 cm above the first line. Patient is then instructed to flex forward as if attempting to touch their toes.An increase of less than 5cm, shows decreased lumbar spine range of motion, and ankylosing spondylitis.

procedures.testName: Chest expansion- Normal chest expansion is ≥ 5 cm.
procedures.procedure: Perform clinical test as described in standard protocols.

procedures.testName: Occiput to wall distance- Normally is 0
procedures.procedure: Perform clinical test as described in standard protocols.

procedures.testName: Tragus to wall distance- Normally is < 15cm

Instruct the patient to flex the arm up to 90 deg with the elbow in full extension.Then ask pt to adduct arm 10-15 deg medial to sagittal plane. Arm is maximally internally rotated and examiner applies downward pressure while patient is asked to resist.  Procedure is then repeated in supination
Yes (Check for adhesive capsulitis– early phase. Carry out active and passive movements)
Currently, do you find it difficult to turn your shoulder in (Internal rotation)
Yes (Check for adhesive capsulitis – freezing phase)

Rule out other causes of stiffness with imaging
Do you feel pain on shoulder elevation?
Can the patient elevate the arm up till the end of the range?
Did you have any history of fall or trauma with hand stretched out?
Did you have any history of loading the shoulder region with weight?
Do you feel a ‘painful click’ when you lift your arm above shoulder height?
Do you feel weakness in your arm when doing activities above shoulder height?
At the early phase of this pain, did you find it difficult to turn your shoulder out (External rotation)
Do you find it easier to move your shoulder backwards (extension)
Do you experience progressive stiffness in your shoulder?
Is the pain worse at night?
Have you had any of the following conditions before
Have you undergone a neurosurgical procedure before?
Previous history of fall or trauma to affected side?

recommendedTests: Patient is in sitting or lying position, the examiner lifts the arn gently into ABduction, external rotation and then extension. Test is positive if Pt senses that humeral head is about to slip out anteriorly and body stiffens in apprehension.
The test is repeated with the anterior part of shoulder protected.

Pt lies supine, arm ABducted up to 90 deg. The examiner places their hands over the shoulder to set the fulcrum base. The humeral head is levered forward by extending and externally rotating arm. The patient immediately becomes apprehensive.
Patient lies supine , scapula is stabilised with one hand while the upper arm is grasped firmly with the other, and manoeuvring is done forward and backward (like a drawer)

procedures.procedure: Perform clinical test as described in standard protocols.
